top_comment.text:
Do Ferraris have a different firing order that makes them sound different 
than an mp4?﻿
top_comment.author: Kenyon Payne

comments.text: +Gonçalo Moura Boa Gonçalo!
comments.author: Ricardo Candeias

comments.text:
+Kenyon Payne their v8's are quite different from normal v8's in the sense 
that they use what is called a flat-plane crank. i'm not an engineer so i 
can not explain to you exactly the difference between this and the most 
common cross-plane crank (something to do with crank pins and their 
arrangement relative to each others) the result being the engine basically 
works like 2 I4 engines, with ignition LRLRLRLR or RLRLRLRL unlike a 
conventionnal v8. this design allows for less internal weight and thus more 
revs and also a simpler exhaust system and thus less weight again. the 
disadvantage is that this engines vibrate quite a lot more.
comments.author: Gonçalo Moura

comments.text: that may very well be true!
comments.author: Ricardo Candeias

comments.text:
+Kenyon Payne If I'm not mistaken Ferrari has contracted Yamaha to help 
with tuning their engine/exhaust sounds on the 458 maybe and the Enzo 
perhaps? And you probably know this but in case you didn't Yamaha doesn't 
just make motorcycles and boat engines, they also make pianos and high 
quality A/V equipment so yeah.
comments.author: boomstick900

top_comment.text: He said hard top Ferrari convertible are a bad choice. Why is that so ?﻿
top_comment.author: Husher Razvan

comments.text: Thank you very much sir !
comments.author: Husher Razvan

comments.text:
Yeah, basically any time you take away some stiffness from the car's body 
(like by removing it's roof) it will corner a little bit worse, and what I 
was saying is that handling characteristics are the main reason for buying 
a Ferrari. Unless you're one of those super rich morons who likes to 
collect pointless status symbols.
comments.author: Noah Benallack

comments.text:
You mean that this prancing pony will somehow suffer for going roofless, 
won't it ?
The "which are sort of whole point for purchasing a Ferrari" line is a bit 
ambiguous. Thanks!
comments.author: Husher Razvan

comments.text:
Taking the roof off of a car that was designed with one reduces it's 
structural rigidity and can negatively effect its driving characteristics, 
which are sort of the whole point of purchasing a Ferrari. That said, a 
modern lightweight car constructed from carbon fiber, which is extremely 
rigid, won't suffer much from the convertible treatment but purists and 
convertible haters will moan regardless.
comments.author: Noah Benallack

captions.text:
First we'll deal with the
controversial bit.
This car belongs to Ferrari.

And I'm probably not supposed
to be driving it.

But I'm not going to
dwell on that.

Someone kind of subcontracted
it to me, let's say.

And if I'm offered
to drive in a
Ferrari I don't ask questions.
I just drive it.

The problem with this situation
is that I'm now at

least a year late to reviewing
the Spider.

You've all read about it and
watched the video so you need
to see something different.

Now I've searched YouTube and
there are lots of beautiful

shoots and factual films, but
there isn't much bad behavior.

I've, therefore, decided in
the interest of original

programming that I'm going
to drive this car
like a complete idiot.
[CAR ENGINE]
[TIRES SQUEALING]
[CAR ENGINE]
[TIRES SQUEALING]
[CAR ENGINE]

Well, I have to say, it's dead
impressive for a car with a

conventional construction
that's got no roof.

570 horsepower, at about
1550 kilograms, at
little bit less, actually.

It's just as fast as you ever
wanted a car to be.
Very direct steering.

I've got the suspension in
full firm at the moment.

But I might just try and soften
it off a bit and see
what it does.
[TIRES SQUEALING]

It might make the car
a bit lazier.
[CAR ENGINE]

I hope you can get some
of this noise.
Because it's--
[CAR ENGINE]

That's the defining
aspect of the 458.
It's normally aspirated.

It makes a noise that
the McLaren just
can't hope to match.
[CAR ENGINE]

The problem with these flippin'
Spiders these days is

they kind of undo my argument
that you have to have a hard
top on the driving front.

I mean, I don't have any
doubt that the Coupe is
a little bit better.

But the difference is
not night and day.
[CAR ENGINE]
[MUSIC PLAYING]

This car is barely
a convertible.

The roof aperture is so small
it's more of a targa really.

And it's quite a fussy shape
from some angels.

Those rear buttresses rise
unexpectedly high.

And those ultra-low profile
tires leave annoying amounts

of vacant space in
the wheel arches.

And this particular example has
63,000 pounds of extras on

top of the 200 grand
list price.

The titanium wheel bolts
are 1,900 pounds.
[CAR ENGINE]

But it's just, it's a very,
very exciting car.

It's very obedient, the
steering's fast.

The controls lack quite
a lot of feedback.

But it's really interesting how
quickly you can kind of

adjust your inputs to the
speed that they require.
[CAR ENGINE]
Ha, ha, ha!
[CAR ENGINE]
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Now I have to apologize, because
I haven't talked about

the clever folding hard
top or the neat gear
shifts in auto mode.
I didn't have the time.

Because remember, I was too busy
driving the 458 Spider

like I was in some sort
of computer game.

But in doing so, I can now tell
you that it's an absurdly
good car to drive.

You can chuck it around like
a cheap rally car, and that
shouldn't really be possible.

Of course I could never buy a
convertible Ferrari for all
the obvious reasons.

But I could just about
forgive anyone who
bought one of these.
[CAR ENGINE]

title: Ferrari 458 Spider Nailed - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS
